Text:
Smoking/vaping (Tobacco - cigarettes, e-cigarettes, cigars, pipes, other) is unhealthy for everyone, especially people with asthma. It can be an inhaled irritant and trigger asthma for some people.

  • Smoke/vapor from tobacco travels through the air and can be found both indoors and outdoors.
  • Smoke/vapor can leave behind the tiniest of particles which can be found on clothes, all household surfaces and car interiors.
  • If You Can Smell Smoke/Vapors, You Can Be BREATHING IN SMOKE/VAPORS!

Secondhand smoke/vapors is the smoke that comes off a burning item such as a cigarette.

  • They can be breathed in by another person nearby the smoker and vapor.
  • They contain nicotine, heavy metals, particles, toxic chemicals and tobacco that can harm the lungs.
  • They can trigger asthma symptoms.

Third hand smoke/vapors are the tiniest parts (residue) of the smoked/vaped tobacco cigarette, e-cigarette, cigar or pipe that remains after it has been put out.

  • They can contain cancer causing substances.
  • They can cling to a person’s hair, skin, and clothes.
  • They can be found on surfaces like furniture, drapes, bedding, carpets, walls, windows and toys.
  • They can be found in dust.
  • They can be found in the interior of cars.
  • Avoid being near anyone who is smoking
  • No smoking indoors, in homes, cars, or wherever the person with asthma may spend time
  • Keep all areas free of smoke
  • Use cover up clothing, pull back hair, wear a hat while smoking outdoors
  • Leave clothes worn while smoking and smell of smoke out of home.
  • Change your clothes, wash hands, face & rinse mouth after smoking.
  •
targets.Name: Ashtray

Text:
AERSOL SPRAYS, like bug sprays, cleaning products and perfumes can cause strong ordors and fumes. These can be inhaled triggers for some people with asthma.

How to avoid - reduce this trigger ?

  • Avoid use of aerosol sprays
  • Choose pest control traps instead of sprays when possible
  • Seek assistance of a pest control professional
  • If a spray is needed, make sure the person with asthma is outside of the home or area this spray is used
  • Air out home after spraying.
  • Make sure you can't smell the odor
targets.Name: BugSpray
Roach
Text:
PESTS: COCKROACHES

The body parts, saliva and waste of cockroaches are allergy triggers for some people with asthma.

How to avoid - reduce this trigger ?

  • Get rid of open food/water sources (Ex: dog bowls) by keeping foods in sealed containers
  • Seal cracks and holes where pests can enter
  • Place bait traps in several areas to attract and trap pests
  • Use pet- and child-proof bait traps and keep them out of their reach

SMOKE

Smoke & odors from candles can be an asthma trigger for some people.

 

  • Avoid use of scented candles
  • Avoid or limit use of indoor candles
  • Use Electronic Flameless Smokeless Candles
targets.Name: Candle
targets.Title: Candle Smoke

Text:
PESTS: RATS

The skin, saliva or urine of rodents can be an allergy trigger for some people with asthma.

  • Get rid of open food/water sources (Ex: dog bowls) by keeping foods in sealed containers
  • Seal cracks and holes where pests can enter
  • Place bait traps in several areas to attract and trap pests
  • Use bait traps that are pet- and child-proof and keep them out of their reach
targets.Name: Rat
targets.Title: Pests

targets.Name: Dog
Text:
FURRY PETS

Furry pets are a common allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma. (EX: Dogs, Cats).

They can spread allergens in a home on surfaces and in the air.

 

  • If allergic to pets, best to remove from home
  • Keep furry pets out of bedrooms
  • Limit furry pets to one area of home
  • Wash furry pets often
  • Vacuum home often

SMOKE from frying/cooking on stove can cause strong fumes and odors. These can be a trigger for some people with asthma.

How to avoid - reduce this trigger ?

  • Use a stove vent to remove smoke from cooking
  • Reduce or avoid strong cooking odors, especially from frying
  • Air out room well
  • Keep person with asthma away from this area until odors and smoke have cleared
targets.Name: Pan
targets.Title: Cooking Smoke

Stove?
targets.Name: Stove

Text:
AERSOL SPRAYS, like scented cleaning products, bug sprays and perfumes can cause strong ordors and fumes. These can be inhaled triggers for some people with asthma.

  • Avoid use of aerosol sprays
  • Use non-scented household cleaning products
  • Avoid cleaning products that have strong odors
  • Clean when the person with asthma is not in the area
  • Air out the room after cleaning
targets.Name: Febreze

Text: ?dogBowl
?dogBowl
targets.Name: dogBowl

Text:
MOLDS are sometimes microscopic (can’t be seen with the eye) fungi or spores. These spores can go into the air and be breathed in. Mold can be an allergy trigger and can cause symptoms to flare for some people with asthma. Mold grows in areas of moisture and high humidity. Common areas are: bathrooms, basements, potted plants, and areas of indoor water leaks.  Outdoors, mold is commonly found in soil & leaves.

How to avoid -reduce this trigger ?

  •  Keep indoor humidity low, best between 30-50%.
  • Use hygrometers (found at hardware stores) to measure indoor humidity
  • Use dehumidifier
  • Limit use of humidifiers or vaporizers as they can cause indoor moisture and mold growth
  • Clean and remove mold promptly
targets.Name: Mold
Garbage
Text: Garbage
Garbage

targets.Name: Faucet
Text: Faucet
Faucet

targets.Name: Fridge
Text: Fridge
Fridge

The fumes and strong odors from BLEACH and other common cleaning products and detergents can be an inhaled trigger for some people with asthma.

          How to avoid – reduce this trigger?

  • Use non-scented household cleaning products
  • Avoid cleaning with products that have strong odors
  • Clean when the person with asthma is not in the area
  • Open windows and doors or use a fan to move the air when cleaning
  • Do not use full strength when directions say to dilute product with water
  • Air out the room after cleaning
targets.Name: Clorox
